properties.name: Sources used in this map for determining a Ghost Town
properties.description:
All ten of the Ghost Towns located in this map were identified by Country Magazine in its article "10 Western Ghost Towns (PHOTOS). (http://www.huffingtonpost.com/country-magazine/western-ghost-towns_b_1982020.html#slide=1658406)"
 
After publishing this map, I decided to add more ghost towns I found on Wikipedia's List of Ghost Towns in the United States. (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ghost_towns_in_the_United_States)

properties.name: Criteria used in this map for determining a Ghost Town.
properties.description:
In making this map I found it funny as to what Wikipedia considers a Ghost Town. Using my criteria, when I zoom in on the town there should be no modern cars in the driveway, if I can enter Street View and see modern houses in good repair that does not qualify as a Ghost Town to me. So my criteria for determining which towns are Ghost Towns includes having one or more of the following:

- Does the town have a history of success as boom town that then declined?
- Is there some indication in Google Map that a town ever existed? 
- Are there visible ruins seen in Google Map such as a dilapidated factory or mine?
- Does the town look abandoned?

properties.name: Digitally walk these ghost towns in 3D.
properties.description: You can walk these ghost towns in 3D using this Non-networked Google Earth KML file (https://docs.google.com/file/d/0B52hHMRyBvEsVzg3Tm05VndxQjQ/edit).                                                                                                                                      Be sure to turn on the Buildings layer in case any are rendered in 3D.

properties.name: Gunsmoke Movie Set Ruins, Johnson Canyon, Utah
properties.description:
Wikipedia (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gunsmoke)

Gunsmoke is an American radio and television Western drama series created by director Norman MacDonnell and writer John Meston. The stories take place in and around Dodge City, Kansas, during the settlement of the American West. The central character is lawman Marshal Matt Dillon, played by William Conrad on radio andJames Arness on television. When aired in the UK, the television series was initially titled Gun Law.,[1] later reverting to Gunsmoke[2]

 

Google Map / Panoramio / www.galenbeck.de (http://www.panoramio.com/user/3240777?with_photo_id=63450731)
